awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Collective behavior in multi-agent systems with active sensing
awd_abstract_narration:
This Faculty Early Career Development Program (CAREER) project will study how large groups of individual agents may collectively use active sensing to improve on the performance of any one individual. In particular, the project seeks to understand and emulate the way in which swarms of bats use echolocation, which is a type of active sensing. In active sensing, for example sonar or lidar, an agent uses the reflection of an emitted signal to learn about its surroundings. Passive sensing, in contrast, relies on the reflection or emission of signals originating elsewhere, such as vision systems that rely on ambient light, or thermal imaging systems that detect heat. In large bat swarms it has been observed that some members seem to navigate by "eavesdropping" on signals emitted by other bats, instead of generating their own. This observation raises many possibilities, including questions of whether eavesdropping changes the behaviors that the swarm can achieve. This project will address these questions through studies on wild bat swarms, then will employ the results in experiments on multiple mobile robots. Of interest will be the ways that simple rules for active sensing by the collective may give rise to complex emergent behavior. The results of this project will benefit national prosperity and welfare by enabling new capabilities in multi-agent networks of mobile robots, for applications such as search and rescue, surveillance and environmental monitoring, package delivery, and construction. This work will also provide insight into the native behavior of bats, many species of which are critically imperiled due to disease and habitat loss. The project includes engagement with K-12 students across Virginia, and supports the development of educational modules that will be disseminated to classrooms throughout the state. 

The role of sensing in the collective behavior of multi-agent systems -- and particularly the impact that active and passive sensing may have on emergent phenomena -- is currently unexplored. Robotic systems are increasingly turning to distributed approaches, therefore understanding how to leverage their interaction over sensing channels could represent a paradigm shift in the control of such systems. This project seeks to provide a new vision for the dynamics and control of multi-agent systems by coupling sensing and communication. This project is motivated by the intercepted sensing observed in bat swarms. The research team will collect quantitative data from field experiments with wild gray bats, perform model-free analyses to determine how collective sensing and behavior manifests in bats, use this insight to inform and validate a model of group behavior with active sensing, and create numerical and robotic testbeds for hypothesis-based exploration of these novel collective dynamics.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Collective motion in multi-agent systems is well known in nature and widely studied in science and engineering. Since collective behavior relies on social interactions, understanding how agents sense each other to interact is critically important for modeling and control. The research supported by this project explored collective motion achieved using active sensing, e.g., echolocation in bats, which relies on a self-generated signal in contrast to passive sensing like vision. The scientific outcomes of this project are fivefold. Firstly, we collected a novel, rich dataset from a wild gray bat colony that comprised video data from a thermal camera array and ultrasound recordings from a microphone array. This data was analyzed for three-dimensional flight trajectories and echolocation behavior for bats in flight, both in their natural environment and in the presence of an introduced obstacle course. Secondly, we analyzed this data with descriptive statistics and model-free methods to conclude that bats share information when they fly together in pairs and orient themselves in relation to each other, which may be a strategy to facilitate acoustic sensing. Thirdly, we used an abstract flocking model to show that flocks attempting alignment are benefited by “eavesdropping” analogous to how active sensing signals can be intercepted, and that flocks moving in the presence of obstacles can only align when each individual’s sensing range is neither too small nor too large. Fourthly, we showed through a numerical study that using passive and active sensing together can benefit simultaneous localization and mapping, a canonical robotics problem. In particular, fusing sensing signals from passive and active sensing may allow teams of robots to create larger maps while not suffering from significantly more error. Fifthly and finally, we created a hardware platform to test aspects of these results, including a two-microphone or “binaural” ultrasonic sonar sensor. Experiments with this sensor in an anechoic chamber showed that passive sonar can indeed be used for sound source localization, which is a fundamental step to demonstrating these results in a physical system. 

In terms of societal impact, this award supported the training of human resources in STEM through positions for one postdoctoral scholar, four Ph.D. students, two Masters students, three undergraduate researchers, and two K-12 teachers. Moreover, this project made a sizeable impact in outreach and informal science education in the Blacksburg, Virginia community, by supporting the development and presentation of activities on bio-inspired design and collective behavior to K-12 students at local camps over two summers. The project also supported positions for two teachers to formalize these activities in shareable, educational kits which will be accessible to all K-12 teachers in our county. Finally, the field data collected as a part of this project represent an unprecedented resource which will hopefully be used in the future to support the study and conservation of gray bats, a federally endangered species.
